perturbation.original_text: 8.4 Privacy. eDiets agrees to treat all consumer data collected from Women.com users on the Women.com Site in accordance with Women.com's privacy and security policies (the "Women.com Data"). Women.com reserves the right to change such policies in its sole discretion from time to time. In no event shall eDiets disclose or otherwise transfer to any person or entity any Women.com Data that individually or in the aggregate identifies the identity, habits or transactions of the Women.com users.
perturbation.changed_text: 8.4 Privacy. eDiets will make reasonable efforts to treat consumer data collected from Women.com users on the Women.com Site in accordance with Women.com's privacy and security policies (the "Women.com Data"). Women.com reserves the right to change such policies in its sole discretion from time to time. eDiets may disclose or transfer Women.com Data.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the strict requirement to adhere to Women.com's privacy policies and allowing eDiets to disclose Women.com data, this clause now contradicts the California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA) and other privacy laws. These laws mandate specific protections for consumer data, including restrictions on its use and transfer. The original clause offered some level of protection, while the modified clause opens the door for potential violations of privacy regulations.

perturbation.original_text: 12.5 EXCEPT AS SPECIFIED IN THIS AGREEMENT, NEITHER PARTY MAKES ANY WARRANTY IN CONNECTION WITH THE SUBJECT MATTER OF THIS AGREEMENT AND HEREBY DISCLAIMS ANY AND ALL IMPLIED OR STATUTORY WARRANTIES, INCLUDING ALL IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF TITLE, MERCHANTABILITY, NONINFRINGEMENT AND FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR USE OR PURPOSE REGARDING SUCH SUBJECT MATTER. NEITHER PARTY WARRANTS THAT ITS WEB SITE(S) OR THE CENTER WILL FUNCTION WITHOUT INTERRUPTION OR THAT THEY ARE ERROR FREE. To the extent that a party may not, as a matter of applicable law, disclaim any implied warranty, the scope and duration of such warranty shall be the minimum permitted under such law.
perturbation.changed_text: 12.5 EXCEPT AS SPECIFIED IN THIS AGREEMENT, NEITHER PARTY MAKES ANY WARRANTY IN CONNECTION WITH THE SUBJECT MATTER OF THIS AGREEMENT AND HEREBY DISCLAIMS ANY AND ALL IMPLIED WARRANTIES. NEITHER PARTY WARRANTS THAT ITS WEB SITE(S) OR THE CENTER WILL FUNCTION WITHOUT INTERRUPTION OR THAT THEY ARE ERROR FREE. To the extent that a party may not, as a matter of applicable law, disclaim any implied warranty, the scope and duration of such warranty shall be the minimum permitted under such law.
perturbation.explanation: By removing "OR STATUTORY WARRANTIES, INCLUDING ALL IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF TITLE, MERCHANTABILITY, NONINFRINGEMENT AND FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR USE OR PURPOSE REGARDING SUCH SUBJECT MATTER", the modified clause attempts to disclaim statutory warranties. California law implies certain statutory warranties, particularly regarding merchantability and fitness for a particular purpose in commercial transactions. Removing the explicit disclaimer increases legal risk.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Commercial Code, Implied Warranty Laws

perturbation.original_text: 15.2 Jurisdiction and Venue. The parties agree that all lawsuits arising out of or related to this Agreement shall be brought in the state or federal courts located in the state of California, San Francisco County, and each party hereby referred consents to the exclusive personal jurisdiction of such courts for such purpose.
perturbation.changed_text: 15.2 Jurisdiction and Venue. The parties agree that all lawsuits arising out of or related to this Agreement may be brought in courts of the party's choice. Each party consents to the jurisdiction of such courts.
perturbation.explanation: This change removes the specified jurisdiction of California, San Francisco County. California law (CCP 395) protects consumers by ensuring venue in the county where the contract was signed, the consumer resides, or the injury occurred. The modified clause allows either party to choose the jurisdiction, potentially forcing a consumer to litigate in a distant, inconvenient location, thereby contradicting California's venue protections for consumers.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Code of Civil Procedure Section 395
